revision.comment: [[Help:Reverting|Reverted]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/Cognate247|Cognate247]] ([[User talk:Cognate247|talk]]) to last version by Yobot
revision.text: {{WikiProjectBannerShell|1= {{WikiProject Catholicism}} {{WikiProject Lutheranism|class=start|importance=mid}} {{WikiProject Biography|living=no|class=Start|auto=yes|listas=Cajetan, Thomas}} {{WikiProject Philosophy|importance=low|class= Start|auto=yes|philosopher=yes}} }} ==Title== I have no objection to the merger, except I would retain the title of this article, as it is his full name. --[[User:CTSWyneken|CTSWyneken]] 02:32, 9 November 2005 (UTC) :[[WP:NCWC]] says "In the titles of articles, cardinals generally go by their full name (both first name and surname) alone, without the title "Cardinal", as "Ascanio Sforza", not "Cardinal Ascanio Sforza", nor "Ascanio Cardinal Sforza". Exceptions are cardinals who are identifiable only by the cardinalitial title (as in the case of a hypothetical Cardinal John Smith), those best known by the title "Cardinal" followed by a surname (as Cardinal Richelieu), and those of the period before the introduction of surnames." A scan of Google Books indicates to me that [http://books.google.com/books?num=100&as_brr=0&q=%22Thomas+Cardinal+Cajetan%22+date%3A1950-2007&btnG=Search+Books Thomas Cardinal Cajetan"] has been used less frequently than [http://books.google.com/books?num=100&as_brr=0&q=%22Thomas+Cajetan%22+date%3A1950-2007&btnG=Search+Books "Thomas Cajetan"]. [[User:Olessi|Olessi]] ([[User talk:Olessi|talk]]) 21:24, 6 December 2007 (UTC) ==conflicting dates== The image says it is of Luther and Cardinal Cajetan in 1557, however both men were dead at this time. Does anyone know the true date? [[User:Adam crymble|Adam crymble]] 01:01, 24 April 2007 (UTC) :: I'd have to check it, but the date is likely correct. Unlike photographs. paintings can be done at anytime after the event, even if the subjects are dead. Then again, with Photoshop... 8-) --[[User:CTSWyneken|CTS]]Wyneken[[User talk:CTSWyneken|(talk)]] 10:02, 24 April 2007 (UTC) == POV? == : his appearance in all the splendor of ecclesiastical pomp only serving to reveal him to Luther as the type of Roman curialist hateful to Germans and German Christianity. This sounds a lot like taking sides with Cajetan, but I can't think of what to replace "reveal" with. -[[User:El Mariachi|El Mariachi]] 21:13, 12 October 2006 (UTC) :: Curiously enough, I read it the other way. 8-) Seriously, if I remember correctly, the text is seeded from a 19th century encyclopedia or two. Feel free to pick up a few sources and correct the language. Does [encarta.msn.com Encarta] have anything? --[[User:CTSWyneken|CTS]]Wyneken[[User talk:CTSWyneken|(talk)]] 09:46, 13 October 2006 (UTC) ==De Vio== Why is he referred to as de Vio? If he is Italian, shouldn't it be di Vio? De is French and Spanish. [[User:Emperor001|Emperor001]] 16:31, 14 August 2007 (UTC) : Spelling is more standardized today. There were many Italian dialects then (and there are still many, but spelling is more standardized today). See the Italian Wikipedia page [[it:Tommaso De Vio]] for verification. — [[User:Lawrence King|Lawrence King]] ([[User talk:Lawrence King|talk]]) 00:42, 13 October 2009 (UTC) == WikiProject class rating== This article was automatically assessed because at least one article was rated and this bot brought all the other ratings up to at least that level. [[User:BetacommandBot|BetacommandBot]] 04:49, 28 August 2007 (UTC) == WikiProject class rating== This article was automatically assessed because at least one WikiProject had rated the article as start, and the rating on other projects was brought up to start class. [[User:BetacommandBot|BetacommandBot]] 04:30, 10 November 2007 (UTC)
